Comment: I keep hearing American pundits blame the Dems and especially Harris’ campaign for the situation in the US, but frankly I can’t help but disbelieve in that narrative. Unless they did somehow succeed in rigging the election in Trump’s favor (as he recently bragged about) the American people had a value proposition in front of them: two human beings to run the country - Trump and Harris. If you chose Trump you were and are objectively wrong. You were either tricked or are too stupid to recognize that you went with the objectively inferior choice.   Your brain has evolved over eons to recogonize patterns and yours failed. Those who chose not to vote also failed to choose the objectively correct choice. The problem isn’t that the choices were both bad, the problem is the American people are too fucking stupid to choose the obviously less bad option. I’m glad to see that our Australian and Canadian neighbors are at least smart enough to make the correct choice after watching us fumble the ball so completely.

Comment: Garbage headline trying to make everything about Trump.  A small handful of voters may have switched votes based on Trump, but there's basically no evidence he had anything to do with it.  The Australian Liberals (conservatives) ran a terrible campaign based on fuel prices that were already coming down, increasing gas prices, an unpopular leader, and no positive messages or at least any that were getting through. The Australian Green party (far left) also did badly, some attribute to their stance on increasing taxes during a cost of living crisis which one Australian Labor party attributed as 'insane'.  Making this about Trump is absurd.

Comment: *Everyone else is recognizing that they're not immune from fascism.*  Local elections in the UK suggest otherwise.  [https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/nigel-farages-reform-uk-party-ahead-by-four-votes-key-election-race-2025-05-02/](https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/nigel-farages-reform-uk-party-ahead-by-four-votes-key-election-race-2025-05-02/)  The Conservative party is fracturing, with the right-wing populists defecting to Reform (the former Brexit party) and Reform replacing the Tories in these local seats  These include working class voters who during an earlier time voted for Labour.  Labour won the last national elections largely because of this Conservative / Reform split dividing the vote.  Things are more fragile than they might appear.

Comment: True but had it not been for Trump, I don’t think Carney would have eked out a win. He did energize people to vote, especially older voters who are more reliable than younger ones, who in this instance supported the conservatives. The fact that Carney crushed in Quebec even though he has zero ties to Quebec, unlike Trudeau, tells you that Trump did save the Liberals from a crushing defeat.   I’m pretty sure that many of Poilievre’s voters were voting mainly for change rather than conservative ideals per se. So the combination of Trump threatening Canada and Trudeau resigning did avert a conservative landslide of epic proportions. People forget but the polling last year had the Liberals go from barely maintaining their official party status to go from to having a strong minority, only three seats from a majority, and Poilievre losing his own seat. This is nothing short of a political miracle. The conservative performance was not as groundbreaking as advertised. It was just a tiny wave of what should have been a conservative tsunami.
Author: Lunarmeric

Comment: Have you not seen the graphs completely shifting the outcome of the election once Carney was nominated and Trump kept up with his 51st state yapping? I think Trump was the major factor as to how the Conservatives had the biggest election bag fumble in history.

Comment: Eh, partially. Dutton ran on Trump-lite when he saw it won in the US, but Albo and the ALP timed it perfectly for when Trump’s actions soured even the conservatives in Australia, making it a noose for Dutton.   Without that, I reckon it’d be a Labor minority as either way the Lib’s had absolutely no policy worth the paper it was written on, but a majority was brought about by all this geopolitical tension for sure.

Comment: The UK's problems stem more from a dysfunctional labour party than anything attractive about conservatives.
